awd_titl_txt: ESPRIT de Corps: Expanding STEM Professionals Roles in Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
In recognition of the national shortage of STEM teachers, especially in high needs schools, collaborators at the University of Houston-Downtown have designed a Noyce Teaching Fellows (TF) project to increase the number of highly qualified science and math teachers in at-risk schools in the greater Houston area.  A complementary goal of this project will be to increase the supply of dual credit STEM teachers.  The project will facilitate the transition of 20 STEM professionals into teaching careers through a program of coursework and professional development featuring (a) a Masters of Arts in Teaching (b) field experiences with teacher/leaders, (c) classroom observations, and (d) an online, professional community of practice.

This project, led by STEM faculty and collaborators from the Urban Education Department, relies on current research on teacher preparation related to improving their ability to thrive in high-needs urban schools with diverse learners and to cope with standard issues that such schools face.  It also takes advantage of current trends for creating online learning communities and training high school instructors to teach college-level courses.  Formative evaluation will involve the assessment of the TF's progress throughout the project, regarding their perceived competence and self-efficacy, certification test scores, and results of observations by faculty, mentors and principals.  Summative assessment will also include the impact of TF's teaching on student achievement scores and career interest.  Results will be presented at conferences and meetings of professional societies such as the National Science teachers Association and the Association of Science-Technology Centers.

por.por_cntn:
The ESPRIT de Corps: Expanding STEM Professionals Roles in Teaching project was funded through an Noyce Track 2 grant. The goals of the project were:

1. Provide fellowships for STEM professionals wishing to enter teaching careers in secondaryGrades 7-12 teaching certification in mathematics or science, a Master’s of Arts in Teaching(MAT) and a UHD Professional Certificate in Dual-Credit (science or mathematics) Teaching so that they are qualified to teach undergraduate lower-level dual-credit mathematics and science courses in high school.

2. Ensure quality field experience opportunities by placing candidates with vetted, high-quality mentor teachers that have experience mentoring preservice teachers as part of working with the UHD Noyce Mathematics and UHD Noyce Science teacher scholarship programs.

3. Provide ongoing professional development and support during the first four years of the fellows teaching in high-needs districts to support success and long-term retention as secondary mathematics or science teachers.

4. Create and foster a collaborative community including UHD faculty, beginning teachers from the existing UHD Noyce Mathematics and Science Teacher Scholarship programs and the Esprit de Corps Noyce Teaching Fellows.

While the goal of the project was to graduate 32 students with a master's in teaching and secondary teacher certification in mathematics and science, we were not successful. Our initial recruitment plan and pool of participant focused on recruiting STEM professionals looking to change careers and become secondary mathematics and science teachers. In the first two years, we were successful in advertising the program and receiving applications; however, these applications did not result in the desired number participants. In particular, the qualified applicants were reluctant to commit to not working full time for the time required to complete the program. Many had families and houses and needed income that our project could not provide. In years 3 and 4, we shifted our recruitment strategy and participant pool to focus on recent graduates of our mathematics and natural sciences programs. These recent graduates were planning on obtaining alternative certification and we were able to recruit them to our program. The additional $10,000/year post graduation was a major incentive to these students who could afford to stay in school for an additional 18 months. With this new strategy, we were able to recruit and accept 2 students per year which was a major increase from the previous two years. Out of 6, four graduated and were full-time teachers in the 2020-2021 school year. 

In terms of the three remaining goals, we have benefited greatly by combining our Track 2 graduates with our graduates from our Track 1 program. In total we have 35 graduates teaching in secondary mathematics in the Houston area. The majority of these teachers have been teaching for more than four years. Before Covid-19, we were able to host meet ups with our students each semester and to further support them. While we have not been able to meet in person, we have continued to support our graduates via email and social media. We hope to restart our meet ups in Fall 2020. 


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: Rebecca Quander
